qas.question: How did early humans locate meat without hunting ?
In addition to finding already dead animals, what other cause of death were their animal finds?
What type of area did early humans avoid?
Lewis Binford suggested that early humans were obtaining vegetables via scavenging in what decade?
Early humans in the Higher Paleolithic lived where?
Which population survived in densely wooded areas?
Which population dispersed through areas of low primary productivity?
Early humans in the Higher Paleolithic collected what?

context: In <b4_0>the 1950s<b4_0/>, Lewis Binford suggested that early humans were obtaining meat via <a0_0>scavenging<a0_0/>, not hunting. Early humans in the Lower Paleolithic lived <b5_0>in forests and woodlands<b5_0/>, which allowed them to collect <b8_0>seafood, eggs, nuts, and fruits<b8_0/> besides scavenging. Rather than killing large animals for meat, according to this view, they used carcasses of such animals that had either been killed by predators or that had died of <a1_0>natural causes<a1_0/>. Archaeological and genetic data suggest that the source populations of <b6_0><b7_0>Paleolithic hunter-gatherers<b7_0/><b6_0/> survived in <a2_0>sparsely wooded areas<a2_0/> and dispersed through areas of high primary productivity while avoiding <a3_0>dense forest<a3_0/> cover.
